dt: {bc}the commander in chief of a navy
{bc}a commissioned officer in the navy or coast guard who ranks above a vice admiral and whose insignia is four stars {dx}compare {dxt|general||}{/dx}
{bc}any of several brightly colored nymphalid butterflies {dx}compare {dxt|red admiral||}{/dx}

et: Middle English {it}admirail, admiral, amiral{/it} "emir, Saracen chieftain, naval commander," borrowed from Anglo-French, borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}admiralis, admirallus, amiralius,{/it} borrowed from Arabic {it}amīr-al-{/it} "commander of the," in such phrases as {it}amīr-al-baḥr{/it} "commander of the sea" (initial {it}adm-{/it} for {it}am-{/it} probably by association with Latin {it}admīrārī{/it} "to {et_link|admire|admire}")

From the 9th century, the Arabic word {it}amīr,{/it} "commander," appears in Medieval Latin documents with a variety of suffixal formations, as {it}amiratus, admirandus,{/it} and {it}admirallus{/it}; the ending {it}-allus{/it} in the latter form has usually been construed as the Arabic definite article {it}al,{/it} which belongs to the following word in collocations such as {it}amīr al-'alī,{/it} "supreme commander." The more specific application of {it}admirallus{/it} to the commander of a fleet originated in 12th-century Norman-ruled Sicily.
shortdef: the commander in chief of a navy
a commissioned officer in the navy or coast guard who ranks above a vice admiral and whose insignia is four stars

dt: {bc}the highest-ranking officer of the British navy

shortdef: the highest-ranking officer of the British navy

dt: {bc}an admiral of the highest rank in the navy whose insignia is five stars

shortdef: an admiral of the highest rank in the navy whose insignia is five stars

dt: {bc}a commissioned officer in the navy or coast guard having either of two ranks:
{bc}one who ranks above a rear admiral (lower half) and below a vice admiral

shortdef: a commissioned officer in the navy or coast guard having either of two ranks:
one who ranks above a captain —called also rear admiral (lower half)
one who ranks above a rear admiral (lower half) and below a vice admiral —called also rear admiral (upper half)

dt: {bc}a nymphalid butterfly ({it}Vanessa atalanta{/it}) that is common in both Europe and America, has broad orange-red bands on the forewings, and feeds chiefly on nettles in the larval stage

shortdef: a nymphalid butterfly (Vanessa atalanta) that is common in both Europe and America, has broad orange-red bands on the forewings, and feeds chiefly on nettles in the larval stage

dt: {bc}a commissioned officer in the navy or coast guard who ranks above a rear admiral and whose insignia is three stars

shortdef: a commissioned officer in the navy or coast guard who ranks above a rear admiral and whose insignia is three stars
